>  > > If your tests take a long time to run, you won't be  inclined to do
> this.
>  >
>  > That's just plain lazy. To anyone who says "I don't want to
>  > run all these tests," I have to ask, "Then why did you write them?!"
> 
> There is plenty of evidence that suggests that running all your functional
> tests is not always the right thing to do.  See the previous postings on
> running only "check-in" tests, or only "database" tests, etc...

It depends on perspective: I believe that running all the tests all the 
time is /the/ right thing to do, but that it's not always practical. 
That said, I have them all running all the time as part of my continuous 
build.

The notion of having "fast tests" and "slow tests", and of running the 
slow tests less often, is quite well understood by now, and it's easily 
handled by having two separate source trees. I honestly have not found 
it useful to classify tests any further than that, and when a fast test 
becomes slow, or a slow one becomes fast, I simply use drag-and-drop 
within Eclipse to move the test case class.
